protocol_name: Epifluorescent Microscopy of Virus Particles Using SYBR Green
protocol_name_html: Epifluorescent Microscopy of Virus Particles Using SYBR Green
description:
Adapted from: Ortmann and Suttle (2009) Determination of Virus Abundance by Epifluorescence microscopy. Ch. 10 Methods of Molecular Biology.

Contact Dr. Steven Wilhelm (wilhelm@utk.edu) or Samantha Coy (srose16@vols.utk.edu) for additional information regarding this protocol.
manuscript_citation: Gainer PJ, Pound HL, Larkin AA, LeCleir GR, DeBruyn JM, Zinser ER, Johnson ZI, Wilhelm SW (2017) Contrasting seasonal drivers of virus abundance and production in the North Pacific Ocean. PLoS ONE 12(9): e0184371. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0184371

groups.group_name: The Aquatic Microbial Ecology Research Group - AMERG (The Buchan, Zinser and Wilhelm labs)

status_info: We use this protocol in our group and it is working

source_data.description: Make a 1% p-phenylenediamine (antifade) solution -- 0.01g + 1mL Milli-Q water.

components.data: Retrieve an 8 uL stock of 1,000x SYBR Green, DI water, and 225 uL 50:50 PBS/Glycerol solutions
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Retrieve an 8 uL stock of 1,000x SYBR Green, DI water, and 225 uL 50:50 PBS/Glycerol solutions

components.data: Place the SYBR Green and antifade solutions into a drawer while working.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Place the SYBR Green and antifade solutions into a drawer while working.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 6 of Epifluorescent Microscopy of Virus Particles Using SYBR Green
source_data.protocol_name: Epifluorescent Microscopy of Virus Particles Using SYBR Green
source_data.protocol_name_html: Epifluorescent Microscopy of Virus Particles Using SYBR Green
source_data.annotation: Only the red light can be on when the solutions are out of the drawer.
source_data.thread_text: Only the red light can be on when the solutions are out of the drawer.
source_data.body: Only the red light can be on when the solutions are out of the drawer.

source_data.description: Fix sample with 0.5x glutaraldehyde.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 7 of Epifluorescent Microscopy of Virus Particles Using SYBR Green
source_data.protocol_name: Epifluorescent Microscopy of Virus Particles Using SYBR Green
source_data.protocol_name_html: Epifluorescent Microscopy of Virus Particles Using SYBR Green
source_data.annotation: If you are going to freeze your sample between slide preparation and visualization, then you need to cool the fixed sample in the dark at 4ºC for 15-30 min, and flash freeze in liquid nitrogen before storing at -80ºC.
source_data.thread_text: If you are going to freeze your sample between slide preparation and visualization, then you need to cool the fixed sample in the dark at 4ºC for 15-30 min, and flash freeze in liquid nitrogen before storing at -80ºC.
source_data.body: If you are going to freeze your sample between slide preparation and visualization, then you need to cool the fixed sample in the dark at 4ºC for 15-30 min, and flash freeze in liquid nitrogen before storing at -80ºC.

components.data: Turn on the vacuum (no more than ~25 mm Hg).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Turn on the vacuum (no more than ~25 mm Hg).
Rinse wells with Milli-Q water.

components.data: While the knobs are turned to open (vacuum on), use the tweezers to add the 0.45 um nitrocellulose backing filter.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: While the knobs are turned to open (vacuum on), use the tweezers to add the 0.45 um nitrocellulose backing filter.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 10 of Epifluorescent Microscopy of Virus Particles Using SYBR Green
source_data.protocol_name: Epifluorescent Microscopy of Virus Particles Using SYBR Green
source_data.protocol_name_html: Epifluorescent Microscopy of Virus Particles Using SYBR Green
source_data.annotation: This filter is used to protect the more fragile 0.02 um Anodisc filter that the viruses are collected on.
source_data.thread_text: This filter is used to protect the more fragile 0.02 um Anodisc filter that the viruses are collected on.
source_data.body: This filter is used to protect the more fragile 0.02 um Anodisc filter that the viruses are collected on.

components.data: Use tweezers to apply the 0.02 um Anodisc filter to the top of the backing filter.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Use tweezers to apply the 0.02 um Anodisc filter to the top of the backing filter.

components.data: Turn the vacuum back on by turning the knobs to open and add the sample in two 500 uL aliquots.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Turn the vacuum back on by turning the knobs to open and add the sample in two 500 uL aliquots.

components.data: Pipette SYBR Green as dots onto a glass petri dish. Make enough dots for each filter.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Pipette SYBR Green as dots onto a glass petri dish. Make enough dots for each filter.

components.data: With the vacuum on, use a needle and tweezers to remove the Anodisc filter and place onto a dot. Turn the vacuum off.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: With the vacuum on, use a needle and tweezers to remove the Anodisc filter and place onto a dot. Turn the vacuum off.

components.data: Put the lid over the plate and back into the drawer to stain for 20 min.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Put the lid over the plate and back into the drawer to stain for 20 min.

components.data: During the wait, label slides with sample ID, dilution, stain, sample volume, and date.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: During the wait, label slides with sample ID, dilution, stain, sample volume, and date.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 17 of Epifluorescent Microscopy of Virus Particles Using SYBR Green
source_data.protocol_name: Epifluorescent Microscopy of Virus Particles Using SYBR Green
source_data.protocol_name_html: Epifluorescent Microscopy of Virus Particles Using SYBR Green
source_data.annotation: You may turn the white light on during this period switching it off anytime the stain is exposed to light.
source_data.thread_text: You may turn the white light on during this period switching it off anytime the stain is exposed to light.
source_data.body: You may turn the white light on during this period switching it off anytime the stain is exposed to light.

components.data: Re-apply Milli-Q to the backing filter and place the stained Anodisc on top. Add another drop of Milli-Q.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Re-apply Milli-Q to the backing filter and place the stained Anodisc on top. Add another drop of Milli-Q.

components.data: Turn the vacuum on again. After the stain has been washed away, use the needles and tweezers to remove the Anodisc--again, with the vacuum still on.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Turn the vacuum on again. After the stain has been washed away, use the needles and tweezers to remove the Anodisc--again, with the vacuum still on.

components.data: On the labeled side, add 18 uL antifade solution, apply the dried Anodisc filter and apply another 18 uL of antifade to the top.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: On the labeled side, add 18 uL antifade solution, apply the dried Anodisc filter and apply another 18 uL of antifade to the top.

components.data: Apply a coverslip and lightly press down so there are no bubbles.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Apply a coverslip and lightly press down so there are no bubbles.

components.data: Store at -20ºC in the dark for up to four months (3-4 weeks recommended). .
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Store at -20ºC in the dark for up to four months (3-4 weeks recommended). .

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 23 of Epifluorescent Microscopy of Virus Particles Using SYBR Green
source_data.protocol_name: Epifluorescent Microscopy of Virus Particles Using SYBR Green
source_data.protocol_name_html: Epifluorescent Microscopy of Virus Particles Using SYBR Green
source_data.annotation: Thawing the sample repeatedly will result in fading of the stain, but you can attempt to re-stain the filter if it fades
source_data.thread_text: Thawing the sample repeatedly will result in fading of the stain, but you can attempt to re-stain the filter if it fades
source_data.body: Thawing the sample repeatedly will result in fading of the stain, but you can attempt to re-stain the filter if it fades

components.data: Turn on all three computers and the shutter.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Turn on all three computers and the shutter.
Open the LAS AF program.

components.data: On the second menu, use the FLUO--Filter cubes L5 and the FLUO incident settings.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: On the second menu, use the FLUO--Filter cubes L5 and the FLUO incident settings.

components.data:
On the fourth menu, click set/clear focus position to desired bottom using the up and down arrows. Once positioned, click "set". You can then move the microscope slide to the desired position to visualize the slide and click "set". These settings will then be saved within the microscope.

 

*Z: up/down (turn the back knob)

*X/Y: Side to side (turn the top or bottom half of the front knob)
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
On the fourth menu, click set/clear focus position to desired bottom using the up and down arrows. Once positioned, click "set". You can then move the microscope slide to the desired position to visualize the slide and click "set". These settings will then be saved within the microscope.

 

*Z: up/down (turn the back knob)

*X/Y: Side to side (turn the top or bottom half of the front knob)

components.data: Once the options are set and the microscope slide is set into place, you can then turn the shutter on/off on the first menu--'IL--Shutter ON/OFF'.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Once the options are set and the microscope slide is set into place, you can then turn the shutter on/off on the first menu--'IL--Shutter ON/OFF'.

components.data:
Rod all of the way in on the microscope -- image only on the micrscope itself

Rod half way in -- image on the micrscope and the computer screen

Rod all of the way out -- image only on the computer screen
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Rod all of the way in on the microscope -- image only on the micrscope itself

Rod half way in -- image on the micrscope and the computer screen

Rod all of the way out -- image only on the computer screen

components.data:
Under the acquire --> acquisition tab:

*To look at a preview of your image, click "live" (delay may occure due to exposure)

*Set desired exposure, gain and intensity.

*To save a desired image, click "capture image". The image will appear on the right screen, where you can adjust the background fluorescence by moving the bar on the black to green scale at the bottom lefthand corner.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Under the acquire --> acquisition tab:

*To look at a preview of your image, click "live" (delay may occure due to exposure)

*Set desired exposure, gain and intensity.

*To save a desired image, click "capture image". The image will appear on the right screen, where you can adjust the background fluorescence by moving the bar on the black to green scale at the bottom lefthand corner.

components.data:
Under the acquire --> experiment tab:

*The captured images will automatically save to the experiment .lif file. This can only be viewed using this software.

*Right clock on an image to rename/delete it.

*Click "save all" to save images to the desired directory.

*To save images in a different format, right click, select export, and chose your desired format (e.g. JPEG, TIFF, or the format requried for your analysis software).
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Under the acquire --> experiment tab:

*The captured images will automatically save to the experiment .lif file. This can only be viewed using this software.

*Right clock on an image to rename/delete it.

*Click "save all" to save images to the desired directory.

*To save images in a different format, right click, select export, and chose your desired format (e.g. JPEG, TIFF, or the format requried for your analysis software).

components.data: With the rod all of the way in, use the fine adjustment knob to locate and resolve the viruses into focus.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: With the rod all of the way in, use the fine adjustment knob to locate and resolve the viruses into focus.

components.data: Count all of the viruses in the grid. The ideal concentration is between 20-40 viruses per grid so that you have enough time to count the viruses before they fade.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Count all of the viruses in the grid. The ideal concentration is between 20-40 viruses per grid so that you have enough time to count the viruses before they fade.

components.data: After counting all of the viruses in the field, look up from the microscope, and move the stage to a different part of the slide to count viruses in another field. It is imprtant to do this without looking so that you can randomly sample your filter and not incur a bias in your counts.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: After counting all of the viruses in the field, look up from the microscope, and move the stage to a different part of the slide to count viruses in another field. It is imprtant to do this without looking so that you can randomly sample your filter and not incur a bias in your counts.

components.data:
Repeat this process until you have counted enough fields to total between 200-300 viruses. Calculate the average, and determine the VLP/mL by the equation:

 

(Avg VLP/field)*(28352.9)*(Dil. factor)*(1000/volume filtered (uL))*((1000+glu. volume (uL))/1000)
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Repeat this process until you have counted enough fields to total between 200-300 viruses. Calculate the average, and determine the VLP/mL by the equation:

 

(Avg VLP/field)*(28352.9)*(Dil. factor)*(1000/volume filtered (uL))*((1000+glu. volume (uL))/1000)
Vortex, keep in the dark.

components.data: Add 6 uL SYBR Green to 235 uL filtered DI. Keep in the dark.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 6 uL SYBR Green to 235 uL filtered DI. Keep in the dark.

components.data: Add 25 uL 1% p-phenylenediamine to the 225 uL aliquot of 50:50 PBS/Glycerol. Keep in the dark.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 25 uL 1% p-phenylenediamine to the 225 uL aliquot of 50:50 PBS/Glycerol. Keep in the dark.

components.data: Once the filter is on, you should add a few drops of Milli-Q and then turn the knobs to closed (vacuum off).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Once the filter is on, you should add a few drops of Milli-Q and then turn the knobs to closed (vacuum off).

components.data: Place the filter onto a Kim Wipe to dry.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Place the filter onto a Kim Wipe to dry.
